The short answer is that they are usually tested in the same testcase as
the enclosing class. Where the testcase are complex enough for a
sepearte testcase class to make sense, refactoring the inner class to
the top level will also typically make sense. For the long answer, I'll
lay out a few cases for you and how they are handled in my experience.

If the class is a tightly coupled private utility, like an iterator or an
event adapter, these are typically tested in the test case for the class.
In the case of an event listener, whether the listener is implemented by
an adapter or the class itself is a minor organizational detail. The
important question is whether the event is dispatched correctly. With
iterators, they tend to be very minor in functionality and extremely
tightly coupled. Iterators are therefore more of a special reference or
psuedopod of the class-under-test than a separate entity and are also
tested in the same testcase.

Sometimes, you use an inner class to define an interface that goes along
with it, such as defining static inner  classes to represent listeners for
events which only that class will generate. The example I have in front of
me right now is a class called LogListener.MaskChangeListener. LogListener
accepts logging events from a Logger for dispatch. A particular
LogListener, however, only accepts events of a particular set of
priorities (e.g. WARNING or above). A Logger wishes to avoid instantiating
messages that will never be processed, so it monitors the priority masks
of its Listeners. It should be obvious that MaskChangeListener is very
specific to LogListener and therefore may as well be a part of it.

In these cases, you have a base class or interface which will be
implemented or extended by some other class. The general practice here is
to create a testcase for that base class (using a stub implementation) and
then the testcases for actual implementations can inherit your abstract
testcase to ensure that invariants are maintained. With the inner class
situation, however, most of the eventual implementations will themselves
be inner classes (adapters) and therefore will not be tested as separate
entities. Further, there really aren't any invariants to be maintained
beyond what the compiler will verify for you- namely, that a method exists
with that signature in the implementing class. So, in this case, too,
there isn't any special testing to be done.

As your inner class gets more complex- perhaps it is an abstract class
with some fields or concrete code- the case for doing a seperate testcase
gets stronger, but so does the case for refactoring. Even if the inner
class needs access to private state which you don't wish to expose, the
dependency can probably be reduced through refactoring to the point where
you can use simple listeners and adapters to connect two top-level
classes.

The borderline case I sometimes run into is an inner class representing a
souped up type-safe enumeration. The enumeration has methods to produce or
parse a human-readable representation of a value and has some special code
to handle serialization safely. If the enumeration is conceptually coupled
to the enclosing class, it makes sense to leave it as an inner class.
There is *some* significant functionality to test (mostly looking for
simple typing errors), which is conceptually different from the
functionality of the top-level class and tends to clutter the testcase a
little if included. I could see a case for breaking this out into multiple
testcase if there were a number of similar inner classes in the top-level
class. Otherwise, I still tend to keep all the tests in one container.

On Fri, 9 Nov 2001 sowmya.srinivasan@... wrote:

> Hello
> I have just started using JUnit.
> I have a few queries.
>
> 1. How do I handle inner classes ?
> 	If I have a class A and this has three inner classes A1, A2, A3 ;
> 		Should I write separate test classes for each of these inner
> classes ? (Atest, A1test, A2test, A3test)
> 		OR should I write just write one test class( TestA) that
> will handle the functions in the inner classes also ?
>
> 2. I am trying to write test classes for an event driven program. How
> feasible is this ?
